dimensions: sheet trimmed to plate: 25 x 16.5 cm (9 13/16 x 6 1/2 in.)
creditline: Bequest of Junius S. Morgan, Class of 1888

makers.displaydate: 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England
makers.displaymaker: Anthony van Dyck, 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England

texts.textentryhtml: Junius S. Morgan (1867–1932); bequeathed to the Princeton University Art Museum, 1932
texts.remarks: as per Jun P. Nakamura & Laura M. Giles

texts.textentryhtml: This etching, of which two states are displayed, was part of an innovative collaborative project on which Van Dyck embarked late in his career. He hired nine printmakers to help him produce a portrait series, later called the Iconography, that included images of several contemporary artists as well as kings, aristocrats, and diplomats. Published after his death in numerous editions, the highly influential series consisted of around one hundred prints, of which the artist etched only fifteen, including this lively portrait of his compatriot Justus Sustermans, who became court artist to the Medici Grand Dukes of Tuscany.

displaymaker: Anthony van Dyck, 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England
caption: Anthony van Dyck (1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England), Justus Sustermans, ca. 1630–33. Etching; 25 x 16.5 cm (plate). Bequest of Junius S. Morgan, Class of 1888 (x1934-1246)
